chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Government should set a universal floor for essential healthcare—covering primary care, preventive services, and protection against catastrophic costs—so access does not depend on income, job status, or geography. Rather than replacing all private coverage, it can standardize basic benefits and patient protections while allowing competing plans and providers to offer additional options. To keep the promise affordable, policy should use simple, measurable quality standards, aggressive anti-fraud efforts, and public negotiation or benchmarking of prices, with targeted help for people and regions that are hardest to serve.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Government should guarantee a universal, affordable baseline of essential healthcare—especially preventive, primary, mental health, and catastrophic coverage—so no one is denied care or driven into medical bankruptcy. It should set clear quality standards, negotiate and regulate to contain costs, and require price transparency and measurable outcomes to protect taxpayers and patients. Within that public guarantee, regulated private plans and providers can offer additional options and innovate, supported by portable coverage and targeted help for vulnerable people, workers, and small businesses.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Government should ensure every person can get essential care—primary, preventive, mental health, and emergency/catastrophic coverage—without fear of medical bankruptcy, while letting people keep or choose private plans and doctors if they want. To protect taxpayers and workers, policymakers should set clear quality standards, require price transparency, negotiate and limit excessive costs, and reduce bureaucracy and fraud. Support should be targeted so seniors, low-income families, rural communities, and small businesses can afford coverage, using partnerships with private providers and local organizations to deliver care efficiently and respectfully.
